insights.title: Alkene Reaction Mechanism Mastery
insights.takeaway: Your understanding of alkene addition reactions is strong, particularly with Markovnikov's rule and carbocation stability patterns.
bullets: Consistently applied Markovnikov's rule correctly in hydrobromination reactions
Demonstrated good understanding of carbocation stability (3° > 2° > 1°)
Successfully distinguished between syn and anti addition mechanisms
Showed strong grasp of regioselectivity in addition reactions
action_items: Practice more anti-Markovnikov reactions with radical conditions
Work on stereochemical outcomes of different addition reactions
Review ozonolysis and other oxidative cleavage reactions
Practice predicting products with multiple functional groups
misconceptions: Occasionally confused syn/anti addition with E/Z isomerism
Need to review why peroxides cause anti-Markovnikov addition
Sometimes forgot to consider stereochemistry in addition reactions

insights.title: Stereochemistry and Chirality Concepts
insights.takeaway: Strong performance on R/S nomenclature and chiral center identification, but need more practice with complex molecules containing multiple stereocenters.
bullets: Correctly identified chiral centers in simple molecules
Applied Cahn-Ingold-Prelog priority rules accurately
Good understanding of enantiomers vs diastereomers
Recognized the relationship between optical activity and chirality
action_items: Practice R/S assignment with molecules having multiple chiral centers
Work on meso compounds and internal planes of symmetry
Study Fischer projections and their conversions
Practice relating 3D structures to 2D representations
misconceptions: Sometimes confused priority assignments with complex substituents
Need to review how to handle double bonds in priority rules
Occasional errors when visualizing 3D orientation from 2D drawings

insights.title: SN1 vs SN2 Mechanism Selection
insights.takeaway: Good foundational understanding of substitution mechanisms, but need more practice predicting which mechanism will predominate under given conditions.
bullets: Understood the two-step nature of SN1 vs one-step SN2
Correctly identified substrate preferences (SN1: 3°, SN2: 1°)
Recognized stereochemical outcomes (SN1: racemization, SN2: inversion)
Applied leaving group and nucleophile strength concepts appropriately
action_items: Practice mechanism selection with borderline cases (2° substrates)
Study solvent effects on mechanism preference (polar protic vs aprotic)
Work on competition problems with multiple pathways
Review temperature effects on substitution vs elimination
misconceptions: Sometimes overlooked solvent effects in mechanism prediction
Need to better understand when both mechanisms can compete
Occasionally confused nucleophile strength with basicity

insights.title: Elimination Reaction Patterns
insights.takeaway: Developing good intuition for E1 vs E2 mechanisms, but need more practice with regiochemistry and stereochemistry of elimination products.
bullets: Understood the role of base strength in mechanism selection
Correctly identified β-hydrogen requirements for elimination
Applied Zaitsev's rule for major product prediction
Recognized when elimination competes with substitution
action_items: Practice Hofmann elimination with bulky bases
Study E2 stereochemistry requirements (anti-coplanar)
Work on predicting elimination products from cyclohexane derivatives
Review elimination reactions of alcohols (dehydration)
misconceptions: Sometimes applied Zaitsev's rule without considering base size
Need to review anti-coplanar requirement for E2 elimination
Occasionally confused elimination regiochemistry with substitution

insights.title: Focus and Attention Patterns
insights.takeaway: Your focus was consistently high during mechanism practice sessions, particularly when working through step-by-step arrow-pushing exercises.
bullets: Maintained 88% average focus score throughout the 2h 15m session
Peak performance occurred during alkene reaction mechanism practice
Attention dipped slightly during stereochemistry nomenclature
Strong concentration during practice problem solving phases
action_items: Continue using step-by-step mechanism practice for optimal focus
Take brief breaks during nomenclature-heavy sections
Use visual aids and 3D models for stereochemistry concepts
Schedule similar 2+ hour blocks for complex organic chemistry topics
misconceptions: Don't assume longer study sessions always lead to better retention
Quality of focus matters more than total study time
Brief breaks can actually improve overall comprehension
